reviews.text:
Despite being operated by Southern, trains are hourly and usually on time (providing that they are running at all.
Platform dates from the 1960’s and is short, only able to serve three carriages of a train. There are convenient shelters on the platforms to keep would-be passengers dry and out the wind. 
The Star Inn is less that two furlongs up the road, which serves excellent food.

This station is barely more than two platforms, with a shelter and a help point on each one. 

Services are regular during weekdays. At the time of my visit at the beginning of April 2018, there were no weekend services, although there were regular tannoy announcements informing the public of a new timetable from 21st May 2018. I would imagine this will include weekend service for the summer season, but check before you travel.

There are no toilets at the station, but there are some located a few minutes walk to the south, on the way to the beach.

The beach is private in places, and about a ten minute walk from the station, if that. There are no facilities other than the toilets, so take what you need if you are visiting for a day at the beach. And whatever you do, check the time of the last train.

There is a nearby camp site with a small shop, but it is private, according to signage.

The station is on the main south coast line between Eastbourne and Hastings.

There is a nearby pub, The Star Inn, if you turn left upon leaving the station ( north ), and turn right at the T junction, towards the east. It offers a good menu and has a very nice garden, suitable for children. There is a baby changing room there.  The pub has many photos and reviews on Google Maps- I've always found it to be pleasant and welcoming.
